text:
Chang-Yu Chang 張昌祐
Principal Investigator
Chang-Yu (he/him) is fascinated by the system-level properties that emerge across different levels of biological organization, particularly as the result of species interactions and evolutionary forces. As an evolutionary ecologist and systems biologist, he enjoys collaborating with field ecologists, theoreticians, and bioengineers. Chang-Yu received his PhD in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at Yale University, where he studied the emergent properties of microbial consortia with Álvaro Sánchez. He then joined the University of Pennsylvania as a postdoctoral fellow, investigating the evolution of plant–microbe symbiosis with Corlett Wood, before joining the Biodiversity Research Center, Academia Sinica.
Outside of science, Chang-Yu is an avid craft beer enthusiast. He’s always happy to chat about microbes and fermentation. You can find his latest drinking notes on Untappd.

title: Laboratory of Microbial Symbiosis, Ecology, and Evolution
text:
Welcome!
We are a new group at the Biodiversity Research Center, Academia Sinica in Taipei, Taiwan. The lab officially launches in November 2025, and we welcome applications at all levels. The official job ads will be announced soon in Join Us!
Our research sits at the interface of ecology, evolution, and systems biology. We study host-associated microbial communities— complex systems layered by hosts, symbionts, and mobile genes—with the goal of uncovering the simple rules that govern them. By integrating fieldwork, laboratory experiments, and theoretical models, we ask when and how diversity across multiple levels of organization emerges, persists, or collapses.

title: Laboratory of Microbial Symbiosis, Ecology, and Evolution
text:
Evolution of Host–Microbe Symbiosis

Facultative symbionts live dual lives: free-living and host-associated. It’s therefore puzzling how and why these microbial symbionts maintain genomic integrity in the everchanging environments over evolutionary time. Using population genomics and laboratory assays, we study how these multitudes of life stages shape the genetic diversity and divergence in microbial symbionts. Our work on host–symbiont systems explores how microbial symbionts adapt across hosts and environments (Chang et al 2025).


Emergent Coexistence & Community Assembly

One fundamental school of thoughts in ecology is the notion of interacting species pairs and its relation to coexistence and ecosystem functioning. However, the absurdly diverse ecosystems in nature challenge this pairwise, “bottom-up” perspective. Alternatively, mechanisms beyond pairwise must be involved. We experimentally showed that microbial communities can stably coexist despite that pairs of constituent species failed to do so (Chang et al 2023). This result unequivocally lended the support for the view that species coexistence is an emergent property of ecological communities.


Microbiome Engineering & Artificial Selection

Microbial communities can be treated as evolving units, subject to artificial selection. As a proof of principle in experimental evolution systems, we found that community function can be improved by selection until heritable variation is exhausted (Chang et al 2020). A further computational study identified key strategies, which invoke stabilizing communities and perturbing ecological states, that extend this improvement by replenishing the heritable variation (Chang et al 2021). These insights point toward a design framework for microbiome engineering, where any communities can be optimized for desired traits.

title: Join Us
text:
We welcome applications from motivated students, postdocs, and research staff who are excited about microbial symbiosis, ecology, and evolution. Our group values a collaborative and inclusive environment where curiosity and teamwork drive discovery.
Our research spans community ecology, microbial ecology, and evolutionary genomics, combining genomics, experimental evolution, and ecological theory.

title: Join Us
text:
Opportunities

Lab Manager
We anticipate hiring a full-time lab manager to help establish and oversee the new lab at Academia Sinica. Responsibilities may include molecular microbiology, plant growth experiments, and lab operations. Previous research or management experience is highly valued.


Postdoctoral Researchers
Interested candidates should email a CV and a brief cover letter outlining:
- Your research background
- Your interest in microbial symbiosis, ecology, or related fields
- Fellowship or grant opportunities you are considering
We are committed to supporting strong applicants in pursuing competitive postdoctoral fellowships.


PhD Students
PhD students are recruited through the Taiwan International Graduate Program (TIGP) – Biodiversity track.
- The program offers a competitive stipend.
- The next application period runs Nov 1, 2025 – Feb 1, 2026 for Fall 2026 admission.
- More details: TIGP application portal
Prospective students are encouraged to reach out before applying.


Undergraduate Students
We welcome undergraduates interested in gaining hands-on experience in ecology, evolution, and genomics. Please email your CV along with a short note about your interests.
Opportunities may be available through Academia Sinica internship programs or university research fellowships.
